text: [MUSIC]
[INTRO]
Hello! It’s good to see you.

It’s been a long time since we did a little
Q&A episode, like a YEAR and a HALF long time.
My bad!

I’m betting you’ve had lots of questions
in that time, so let’s answer some of ‘em.

I’m also going to announce the challenge
question winners from our “Hurricanes”

video, those 5 people will be getting a free
IOTBS t-shirt… stay tuned and we’ll do
that at the end of the video
But NOW, it’s time for…
ASK JOE STUFF
ASK JOE STUFF ASK JOE STUFF ASK JOE STUFF

On Twitter, Israel Fernandez (@israawesome)
asked

Which has been your favorite vídeo to make,
and why?

Without a doubt, my favorite video to make
was “Is Big Data Getting Too Big?” because

dressing up like a 1980s cable access host
has always been a dream of mine, that was

probably the most fun we’ve had shooting
a video.

And it probably means that trapped somewhere
inside me is a really dorky 80s kid.

Oh wait, that’s actually exactly what I
am.

Andrew did an incredible job on the graphics
for that one.

I hear if you watch it in like 240p then some
people actually thought it was an old VHS
video.

I also loved my collab with Physics Girl and
ArcAttack, cuz I got to dress up in chain

mail and get struck by lightning, and my collab
with Jake from Vsauce3 about AI was awesome

too because Jake is awesome and he looks really
good in a Star Trek uniform.

And also our Minecraft video because we shot
most of it IN Minecraft.
You know what?
I love all of my videos!

On Instagram, @darwinning21 asks
What is your favorite type of biology and
why?

Also, what was it like working with Aaron
Pomerantz (@nextgenscientist)?
Working with Aaron was awesome!

Aaron is an awesome insect biologist with
his own YouTube channel and we recently traveled

to the Peruvian rainforest together to make
a bunch of videos.

It was a totally life changing experience,
being in one of the richest and most biodiverse
places on Earth.
Um, it was also very sweaty.

Stay tuned for our videos from Peru starting
in the next couple weeks!

It would be impossible to pick a favorite
part of biology!

Biology is by far my favorite subject, which
is why I got my PhD in it.

I can’t pick a favorite because the more
I’ve learned about biology, the more I’ve
seen that every field within it is connected.

If you want to understand insects, then eventually
you’ll want to ask questions about their

genetics, and their evolution, and their habitat
and ecology, and the interesting physics that

gives them their color, and the chemistry
that lets them eat this food or makes them
toxic.

It all feeds into the larger story about how
life works, and I love the WHOLE story, not
just one little part.

On Facebook, Joshua Freshwater asked
What's the most complicated video you've had
to make, and was it worth the effort?

Any time you’re trying to condense some
of the biggest and most mind-blowing parts

of science into 5 minutes, it’s going to
be a tough job, but I think the MOST complicated

might be “Why Are We Multicellular?” and
“The Most Important Moment in the History
of Life”.

I actually wrote these two videos to kind
of go together as one, because they describe

two of the most important transition points
in evolution, how we went from bacteria and

archaea to complex cells like ours, and how
life became multicellular, which were kindof
important.

These are things that took billions of years
to play out, and all the biochemistry and

genetics and other biology that tells the
story could fill a whole college class, and

a lot of it I didn’t learn or understand
until I was in graduate school, so yeah…
getting those into a couple videos was TOUGH.

But totally worth it, those early moments
in the evolution of life just don’t get

enough attention, it’s some of my favorite
writing and research I’ve ever done.

On Instagram, @ariwilliamw asks
What field did you get your PhD in?
Cell and molecular biology!
From this place.
HOOK EM.

I studied gene editing and these ancient weird
genetic things that kind of jump around inside
genomes.

If you really want to know more, I guess I’ll
put a link to my dissertation or something
down in the description.

Should be great if you’re having trouble
sleeping!

On Facebook, Wong Ee Lin asks
Can we travel through time…?
Yes!

In the forward direction, at the rate of one
second per second.
Oh, you wanted more than that?

Ok, so get yourself going very close the speed
of light, or hang out near something massive

like a black hole, and thanks to relativity,
time will pass more slowly for you compared

to someone watching you, which is pretty much
the plot of the movie Interstellar, and also
this awesome recent video from Vsauce3.
Backwards time travel… probably not.

We’d sorta have to bend spacetime back on
itself, so that we could jump from one point,
here and now, to another, here and then.
It’s the old “wormhole thing”.

Physicists like Kip Thorne, who worked on
a lot of the science for Interstellar, think

wormholes, these little theoretical doors
that connect two different points in space
and time, MIGHT be able to do this.

The math works out, mostly, but it would involve:
A) making a wormhole, and B)

accelerating it close to the speed of light,
two things that we don’t know how to do
and which actually might be impossible.

On Facebook, Marie Goddette asks
Can dogs "tell time"?

Every day I know exactly when it’s 8 AM
because my dogs look at me and start whining
for breakfast, like CLOCKWORK.

They can’t ACTUALLY read a clock, but they
can definitely sense “time”, lots of animals
can.

Most complex organisms on Earth, from plants
to dogs to birds to humans, have some kind

of programmed “biological clock” we call
“circadian rhythms”.

They work a little differently in different
organisms, but there’s basically genes and

cells that respond to things like light and
dark, and then adjust the organism’s behavior
accordingly.

I talked about plants sense the length of
days in my recent “Do Plants Think?”

video, and we talked about how our brains
sensing light and dark affects our sleep cycle
in “Why Do We Have To Sleep?”

On Instagram, @soot.soots asks
Are you a runner?
You ran a marathon, right?
Yes, I love running!

I did run a marathon, I even made a video
about it.

People who don’t run might think I’m crazy
for saying this, but running is like my form
of meditation.

I put on a podcast or a good audiobook and
just let my mind run while I run… it’s
great.

I also get kind of stir crazy unless I go
play outside enough, which means I’m basically
5 years old.

On Facebook, Sandra Thompson asks
Hi Joe!

:) What do you think is a superior weapon
a lightsaber or sonic screwdriver?
Definitely the lightsaber!

But that’s because a sonic screwdriver isn’t
a weapon, it’s a tool.

And that’s what makes it so much cooler
than a light saber.

It’s like Gallifreyan duct tape, a Time
Lord’s swiss army knife…

It’s about the creativity and smarts of
the person holding it.

Although a light saber does have one advantage,
it works on wood…

On Instagram, @tobym13 asks
What's your favourite science fact?

If you took all the viruses in the ocean and
stacked them end to end, they would reach
200 million light years into space.

That’s about 4 times farther away than the
Virgo galaxy cluster.
Yep.
It’s true.
Source down there.

On Twitter, @onelettertooman asks:
Is a pirate TWICE as likely or HALF as likely
to win a staring competition?
Excellent question!
First one to blink loses?
I assume the pirate is wearing an eye-patch?

If the pirate is using their non-eye-patch
eye for the staring contest, then they have

the same chance of winning the contest as
a non-pirate.

I dunno about you, but I always blink my eyes
together.

But if they’re using their eye-patch eye
then they’re almost guaranteed to win, just
ask my old friend One Eyed Willy…
